qas.question: What standard did Unicode inherit involving a Thai language?
Why has Thai alphabet support been criticized?
How are the Thai characters ordered incorrectly?

answers.text: Thai characters. The vowels เ, แ, โ, ใ, ไ that are written to the left of the preceding consonant are in visual order instead of phonetic order

qas.question: How are Thai characters written similarly to other Unicode scripts?
What standard did Unicode create for the Thai language?
Who criticized the order of Thai characters?
What kind of machine was the Thai Industrial Standard 620 not implemented on?

plausible_answers.text: The vowels เ, แ, โ, ใ, ไ

qas.question: What are written to the right of the preceding consonant?

context: <b5_0>Thai alphabet support<b5_0/> has been criticized for <a1_0>its ordering of <a2_0>Thai characters<a1_0/>. <b7_0>The vowels เ, แ, โ, ใ, ไ<b7_0/> that are written to the left of the preceding consonant are in visual order instead of <b3_0>phonetic order<b3_0/><a2_0/>, unlike the Unicode representations of other Indic scripts. This complication is due to Unicode inheriting the <a0_0><b4_0>Thai Industrial Standard 620<b4_0/><a0_0/>, which worked in the same way, and was the way in which Thai had always been written on <b6_0>keyboards<b6_0/>. This ordering problem complicates the Unicode collation process slightly, requiring table lookups to reorder Thai characters for collation. Even if Unicode had adopted encoding according to spoken order, it would still be problematic to collate words in dictionary order. E.g., the word แสดง  [sa dɛːŋ] "perform" starts with a consonant cluster "สด" (with an inherent vowel for the consonant "ส"), the vowel แ-, in spoken order would come after the ด, but in a dictionary, the word is collated as it is written, with the vowel following the ส.
